research_paper.title: Personal Branding: A Systematic Literature Review

level_1: Research says personal branding means showing your real skills online.
It is how people see you on LinkedIn and GitHub.
Your photo, bio, and posts build trust with recruiters.
LinkedIn shows your story, skills, and achievements.
GitHub shows your coding work and projects.
level_2: Studies explain that a good brand is clear, honest, and updated.
LinkedIn branding means writing a simple summary and clear headline.
GitHub branding means active, public repos with good READMEs.
Research shows freshers get more calls if they share project links.
The paper says branding works best when you connect both profiles.
level_3: Researchers highlight writing useful posts and blogs to stand out.
They show how commenting nicely builds trust.
GitHub shows teamwork skills with open source work.
LinkedIn shows your network and endorsements.
The study explains how your brand proves you can deliver work.
level_4: Advanced branding includes mentoring juniors online.
The paper says thought leadership grows trust in communities.
Research says regular updates and blogs keep you relevant.
Good branding builds your image as reliable and skilled.
LinkedIn + GitHub together show full proof of your skills.

level_1: Using LinkedIn to get internship calls.
Showing a GitHub link to prove skills.
level_2: Writing a clear summary and linking projects.
Keeping GitHub public with README files.
level_3: Sharing posts to tell people what you built.
Fixing issues and replying on GitHub.
level_4: Speaking at tech groups to show your brand.

level_1: Companies look at LinkedIn before shortlisting.
level_2: Hiring managers check GitHub for real code.
level_3: Teams like devs with clear branding proof.
level_4: Leads guide others to share good branding online.

level_1: Keep your info clear and true.
Use a clean photo and simple words.
level_2: Link your coding projects to your profile.
Write in your own words, don’t copy.
level_3: Join open source and show real work.
